properties.media:imagetext:
CNAC I presume has approximately four hundred employees. The
Aviation Commission got a few mechanics from us but we havent had
one man join a fighting force.
We hear a lot about
guerilla warfare, in the papers. Also we hear
a lot about skirmishes
and big battles pending along the Lunghai
Railway. While in Hankow last week I talked to one of the best known
correspondents who had just returned from that area. He left he
said because there was nothing going on. He thought
the Japanese
could march any where they want and take any place they want, he
could not understand why they were so inactive. The night before
I left Hankow I
invited Donald and Capt. McHugh to dinner. I do
not wish to quote either of these gentlemen, they
told me
very interesting and amising stories,
some
but nothing to indicate I
was
VEry
far
wrong in my
views. Donald did seem to think the
Industrial
situation in Japan was worse than
generally known
and might become
effective soon, also that Japan was having much
difficulty getting raw material. No doubt, so is China.
It
seems
to me however that Japan could continue this war, as it is now
being fought, for several
years and at the end have more raw
material, supplies than China had in the beginning. Any financial
crash or political upheavel in Japan in my opinion will not come
If at all, until after the war. Unless of course something aw
unexpected happens.
I do not wish to appear either pessimistic or optomistic. CNAC
is doing as well
as I ever expected, better in fact, we are
staying in business and paying expenses. It would befoolish for
me to say I have no idea of the outcome, that is too obvious.
I have reached only one firm conviction, which e may be all
wrong,
and that is, that no matter how this war ends, either in a
complete victory for Japan or an over-whelming victory for China
or any point between these two extremes, PAA's only hope for
salvaging something out of the China investment depends entirely
on what there is left to salvage when the war is over. If we can
render a service to China during this crisis, and I think we
certainly
are, this may in turn be helpful to PAA after the war
is over, if China comes out of it even partially in tact. If Japan
wins the war completely and enforces harsh terms then PAA's only
chances to recover anything is for CNAC to be going concern,
no matter uncertain the going may be. Our head may be bloody
but
if it is unbowed they cant count us out. At least I hope they cant.
That added up outlines all I know and plan in China. It is clear I
do not know much and my plans are very modest. It is a weak effort
at best but it seems to me it has to be made. I dont like the job
to talk myself into a job Mr. Trippe has me thrown out of his
0 520/156Plos
properties.wof:name: correspondence: William L. Bond to Harold M. Bixby
